Row.Text: As foreign trade increases, an Ottoman noble imports untold numbers of tulips for his lavish garden parties. Many see this as a sign that the empire is thriving, but others call it wasteful extravagance.
Life is a party. Keep the tulips coming.

Together, the Grand Bazaar and the Sultanahmet Camii watch proudly over one of the busiest parts of {1_story_city}. To one side, the allure of handwoven textiles, aromatic spices and more. To the other, the call to devotion and reflection.
All that is of value passes through the Grand Bazaar.
In the Sultanahmet Camii, all may know themselves.
The Barbary pirates abscond to their ships with pillage, already raising sail as their victims count their dead. They will be gone well before the fires have cooled.
Ensure they do not withhold plunder.
Only the best sail with Sayyida al Hurra.

As a shift towards Baroque architecture sweeps the empire, traditionalists decry what they see as a foreign contamination of Ottoman art. But others contend that foreign knowledge keeps Ottoman forces competitive.
The empire's strength is rooted in tradition.
The empire changes, or it dies.

Once the pride of the Ottoman military, the Janissary Corps struggles to maintain its relevance in the face of ever more advanced enemies. Military leaders look to modernize, though the Janissaries are not known for their cooperativeness...
They will be taught to cooperate.
{1_reward} with 5 Levels, but +2 Maintenance on Janissaries.
Not battle-hardened, but with extensive training, the new commander surveys the janissary regiments.
Their weapons are obsolete, not they.
Newly armed and outfitted, the Janissaries march forth as the juggernaut they have always been.
The Janissaries are not the priority.

Ambassadors returning from abroad describe a new art form called "opera" – musical epics with elaborate costumes and sets. It is a far cry from the shadow plays and improvised comedies enjoyed by locals in shops and coffee houses.
The pratfall is the highest form of art.
An ortaoyunu troupe performs on a makeshift stage in the center of a shop. As Pişekar slowly realizes that Kavuklu is standing right behind him, the audience crowded around them erupts in laughter.
Place a Specialist on a Department Store.
The empire must keep up with the times.
The cream of Ottoman society fills the stalls and boxes of the opera house for the premiere of a new tragedy. As Antonina's aria finale reaches its crescendo, there is not a dry eye in the house.
Place a Specialist on an Opera House.

Ushering his students out of the mekteb after lessons, the şeyh eyes the new rüşdiye nearby with suspicion. It is said that students there must follow strict lesson plans and read from state-issued textbooks, with no regard for children's curiosity.
Is that what they call progress?
The rüşdiye will produce the empire's future.
Not if the ulema has anything to say.
All around the külliye complex, imams conduct prayers, müderrisler lecture students, and doctors minister patients. Here is determined the soul of the Devlet-i Aliyye, the divine state.
Now {1_story_city}, too, has entered the Protected Lands – so says the külliye.
Have a captured Settlement with a Külliye.

Further excavations in the old arena reveal a tall, red granite obelisk bearing Egyptian inscriptions. Wondering how it came to {1_STORY_CITY}, archaeologists are drawn to the reliefs on the obelisk's base.
The Good Doctor in the Ottoman Empire

Dr Rizal shares a mutual love for poetry with an Ottoman intellectual over hot, fragrant coffee. Just when they've decided to browse the books at a nearby sahaf, a troop of janissaries comes marching down the street.

Amidst the sacking of {1_story_city}, a general orders an obelisk of red granite to be taken away, but the base is damaged in the process. Though dismayed at first, the general sees this as an opportunity to rededicate the monument with new reliefs.
